headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Doug Bettinger, Chief Financial Officer of Avago Technologies.
After the market closed today, Avago distributed a press release and financial tables describing our financial performance for the first quarter of fiscal year 2012. If you did not receive a copy, you may obtain the information from the Investors section of Avago's website at www.avagotech.com. This conference call is being webcast live, and a recording will be available via telephone playback for one week. It will also be archived in the Investors section of our website at avagotech.com.
During the prepared comments section of this call, Hock and Doug will be providing details of our Q1 fiscal year 2012 results, background to our Q2 2012 outlook and some commentary regarding the business environment. We will take questions after the end of our prepared comments.
In addition to U.S. GAAP reporting, Avago reports certain financial measures on a non-GAAP basis. A reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the tables attached to today's release. Comments made during today's call will primarily refer to our non-GAAP financial results.
Please refer to our press release today and our recent filings with the SEC for information on the specific risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements made on this call.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Hock. Hock?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to start today by reviewing some of the recent -- some our recent business highlights, and then Doug will provide summary of the first quarter financial results.
Now as you may have seen from our earnings announcement just out, revenue for the quarter of Q1 fiscal '12 was at the top end of our guidance at $563 million, down 10% from last quarter, but up 2% year-on-year from the first quarter 2011. Now, results for our wireless communication end market came in much stronger than normal seasonality, and our wireline -- wired infrastructure, is the same, wireline market was basically holding up in line with expectations.
The gains is very favorable to end markets, however, we experienced a rather down industrial end market. Now generally, macroeconomic conditions have the biggest impact on our industrial market. In particular, we are seeing industrial spending in China continuing to be weak. And that has also continued to impact demand from our industrial OEM customers worldwide.
As we have also discussed previously, we also have seen the impact from the flooding in Thailand, which has exacerbated our ability to ship our industrial products last quarter. But as we sit here today, I feel demand for our products has stabilized in this industrial segment, and in some situations, may actually be recovering. 
However, we forecast too that some spending uncertainty remains, especially in Europe and in emerging economies.
In summary, we now believe our Industrial business has bottomed, but we've only seen limited signs of recovery. 
So now let's turn to results from each of our target markets. Within our wireless communications target market, as you know, we manufacture FBAR duplexers, power amplifiers, some light and proximity sensors and optical navigation devices for feature-rich and smart mobile phones. We also produce RF components for wireless base stations. Here, sales from our wireless communication target market represented 45% of our first quarter revenues, and our revenue from this market declined 2% from the preceding quarter, but rose 26% above Q1 last year.
Now to remind everyone, seasonality in wireless for us typically means revenue decline in the low-double digits on a percentage basis in Q1. But we obviously, showed much stronger than typical seasonality in seasonal performance. 
And there's a good reason for that. We have been and will remain focused on picking programs where we can insert content, products with high content, that is very differentiated from most standard commodity life products. 
Clearly, we saw the benefits of picking the right programs this particular quarter, and frankly, we would have grown sequentially in RF if not for our OFN and base station for component business been down.
Looking ahead to the second quarter of fiscal 2012, we expect this momentum to carry into what would have been another typically weak seasonal quarter. As a result, we expect overall wireless revenue to be slightly up compared to Q1.
Next, within wired infrastructure, as also you may know, we design high-speed SerDes ASICs as well as produce optical transceivers for enterprise networking data center switching in the high-speed computing application. 
Revenue for our wired infrastructure represented 29% of our total Q1 sales. Our sales from this end market declined 8% over Q4, but grew 6% from that of a year ago -- from the quarter a year ago. Revenues from wired infrastructure were in line with our expectation, right at the beginning of the quarter. 
To give you a little more color, we experienced here during this quarter correction in supply-chain among several large OEMs in this segment. Notwithstanding, we managed to offset these because certain of our larger OEMs showed strength in carrier routing and data center switching.
Turning to Q2, with supply chain pretty much normalized today, we expect overall revenues from wired infrastructure market to increase mid-single digits quarter-on-quarter, driven by continuous strength in core routing and increase in sale of our ASICs and proprietary fiber optics into data center applications.
Next, in industrial and automotive electronics, we manufacture and sell optocouplers, motion encoders and industrial fibers. Net revenue from this end market accounted for 20% of our Q1 2012 revenues. Revenues here declined 29% compared to the prior quarter and declined 31% from the same quarter a year ago. 
Demand continued to soften during this quarter, but we also experienced a rather dramatic supply-chain correction with not just our distribution channels, but with also some of direct OEMs and industrial OEMs as well. Looking at resale, however, specifically North America held up, Europe and China were down significantly. Japan was down only slightly and overall, worldwide resales were down just around 10% against, as I mentioned earlier, a quarter-on-quarter revenue decline in ship-in revenues, I should say, of 29%.
As I also said earlier, it does look like we are now at the bottom in industrial, even though we don't see clear signs of a recovery. Accordingly, Q2, we expect revenue for industrial to be up mid-single digits as we replenish some of our resale inventory, even though we do expect resale to remain flattish in this current quarter.
Finally, in consumer and computing peripherals target markets, we manufacture navigation sensors for optical mice and motion sensors for printers. Revenue from this target market represented only 6% of our first quarter 2012 sales. Revenue here increased 27% of a small base, no question, from last quarter in group 14% year-on-year. We expect this business to be somewhat down in Q2.
So in summary, let me say wireless was strong. Wired infrastructure maintained, and industrial was significantly down due to supply-chain contraction, and continuing weak macro conditions. 
Looking forward to Q2, we expect trends to remain much the same. Wireless and wired infrastructure continue to look good, and the macro situation's stabilizing, industrial should be flat to slightly somewhat up. In other words, okay. And as a result, we believe total revenue for Q2 will increase. Our guidance between 1% to 4%, as compared to Q1. 
So with that summary, let me now turn the call over to Doug for more a detailed review of our first quarter fiscal 2012 financials.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Hock. Good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for joining the call. Before reviewing the first quarter fiscal 2012 financial results, I want to remind you that my comments today as always, will focus, primarily on our non-GAAP results. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release that we issued today and it's also available on our website at avagotech.com.
Revenue of $563 million in Q1 represents a decrease of 10% from last quarter and an increase of 2% versus the same quarter a year ago. The sequential decrease was at the high-end of our guidance. Revenue from our wireless and consumer target markets came in better than we expected, and revenue from our industrial market came in well below our expectations, as Hock told you. 
I've mentioned that revenue in the consumer market benefited from a discrete IP sale. Resales and distribution declined in Q1 relative to Q4. Our sales into the distribution channel were down much more than the decline in distribution resale and as a result of that, inventory and distribution obviously, has declined.
And while resale has declined in Q1, we expect them to be flattish to slightly up in Q2. Q1 gross margin was 50.6%. This was down from last quarter and essentially at the midpoint of our guidance. Gross margin was affected by a number of factors this quarter. The biggest driver of the sequential decline in gross margin was lower revenue from our high-margin industrial end market. Relative to our expectations, our lower margin wireless business was strong and our higher-margin industrial business was soft. This negative mix was partially offset for non product-related revenue, again the discreet IP sale that I mentioned. 
Additionally, we realized greater-than-forecasted cost reductions in our wireless business. And I'd just point out the potential negative impact of the additional spending that we needed to incur from the Thai flooding was largely offset by insurance claims.
During the quarter, R&D expenses decreased $1 million to $78 million due to tight cost controls. SG&A decreased by $5 million to $44 million, also driven by those same cost controls but additionally, driven by a reduction in our litigation expenses. As a percentage of sales, R&D increased to 14%, while SG&A remained at 8% of net revenue. 
Income from operations decreased by $28 million sequentially to $163 million, and represented 29% of net revenue. 
Q1 income from operations compares with income from operations of $191 million in Q4 and with $169 million in Q1 of last year.
Taxes of $5 million for Q1 were slightly higher than we guided at $4 million due to the jurisdictional mix of income. These results translated into net income of $156 million, which is down 16% from last quarter. Q1 earnings per share of $0.62 compares with $0.73 in Q4 and net income in Q1 of 2011 was $165 million or $0.65 per diluted share. 
Total share-based compensation in Q1 was $11 million. The breakdown of expense for Q1 includes $1 million in cost of goods sold, $4 million in R&D and $6 million in SG&A. In Q2, we anticipate share-based compensation will be approximately $14 million, growing as we complete our annual equity grants this quarter. And just a reminder, the company's definition of non-GAAP net income excludes share-based compensation expense. 
So now, let me move to the balance sheet. Days sales outstanding came in at 50 days. This was up 2 days from the prior quarter due to the timing impact of Chinese New Year on our collections. Inventory came in at $192 million, which was down 1% from last quarter, and this translated to days on hand of 63 days. I do think it's possible that inventory could grow somewhat next quarter. 
And now, cash flow. At the end of the quarter, our cash balance was $819 million. We generated $139 million in operational cash flow. During Q1, we repurchased and canceled approximately 2.6 million shares and this consumed $79 million of cash. Capital expenditures in Q1 were $47 million, which was slightly higher than our expectations for the quarter. And this was due to expenses associated with bringing secondary facilities online after the Thai flooding. We expect CapEx in Q2 will be in the range of $52 million to $57 million. The sequential increase is due to the capacity additions in our wireless factory that we mentioned last quarter.
Also in Q1, we paid more than $40 million in annual bonus payments that were based on our fiscal year 2011 performance. 
And finally, on December 30, 2011, we paid a quarterly cash dividend of $0.12 per ordinary share, which consumed $29 million of cash. This dividend was raised by $0.01 from the prior quarter. And just to round out the cash flow discussion, I thought I'd point out now that we have been returning cash to equity holders for 5 quarters that cumulatively, we have paid $115 million in dividends and have consumed $172 million in share buybacks.
Now let me review the balance of our non-GAAP guidance for the second quarter of fiscal 2012. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we do not intend to update this guidance. Revenue is expected to increase 1% to 4% sequentially. Gross margin is expected to be approximately 50.8% plus or minus 75 basis points. Operating expenses are estimated to be approximately $124 million, which is up slightly from Q1. 
Interest and other is forecasted to be approximately 0. Taxes are forecasted to be approximately $7 million and finally, the diluted share count forecast is for 254 million shares.
That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, please open up the call for questions.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext:
[Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from the line of Romit Shah 
from Nomura.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: Hock, I had a couple of questions on the Industrial business. Just given that sales are down close to 40% from the peak and at the same time, you're seeing signs of resales at least stabilizing. It would seem it's just a matter of when, it's just a matter of timing in terms of when the Industrial business will snap back. Can you give us some visibility into that?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: Well, you've got everything right so far. The only thing I didn't say and it was purposely so was when we will snap back, the answer is, I don't know when, Romit. But we do see, and this might be clutching at straws I know people want to see what they see, there's no further deterioration. That's pretty clear what we are seeing. But we see some improvement, but is that big enough to say there is a snap back happening? No. So my answer is very limited signs of recovery though things are not getting worse in industrial.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: In terms of your near term booking patterns, have you seen any sort of noticeable change post-Chinese New Year whether it's industrial or some of the other segments?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: We see very different booking patterns for these different segments, actually, which maybe, I didn't make clear enough in my remarks. But it is a very mixed market, what we see out there. Wireless business, as you -- and you probably heard me say, continues to be very strong in the way they booked. Our wired infrastructure is also very robust in the way booking is happening. Industrial, obviously, over the last 4, 5 months, have been very weak, 6 months actually, have been weak. It has improved somewhat but not meaningful enough and sustained enough for me to pass any judgment at this point other than to say, we're pretty sure resale is holding up at flat it's at the -- kind of at the bottom. Snapback or recovery is not that clear yet. And because the improvement we have seen so far in industrial, and we have seen it, it's really because inventory is down so low, people have to replenish. The question is after they replenish, what then? And the data is still not out there. But there is replenishment and we are filling this replenishment, which is part of the reason why we are seeing industrial this quarter, Q2, we're guiding to be up single digits, Mid-single digits. It is the replenishment. It is not necessarily in a fundamental recovery or snapback of industrial spending. Now that might change if emerging economies start driving, spending in industrial infrastructure one more time as they did in 2010. But that thing is not very obvious as yet.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: Ed, Hock Tan here. We talk about pad architecture in fact, last conference call or the one before that for us. Pad architecture, which is duplexer with power amplifier in a module is something we have been promoting for a while. And obviously, we do it with RF very nicely. And this is something that's been going on. Nothing rather unusual. Now there are some OEM customers who has a preference for it versus others who prefer to use discrete components. And we address them were they will and it fits in with us and so in terms of where -- one you mentioned is concentration of revenue in wireless. Today's -- our concentration is pretty spread out among many handset guys because, as I mentioned, we chase programs not on customers as on products, products that we can differentiate ourselves. And so we have a lot of our products scattered all over multiple phone makers. In fact, just about every major OEM and smartphone maker, we probably have at least one, if not, multiple programs today. And that's because of the nature of products. We have integrated modules, front-end modules, that has both power amplifier and duplexers already shipping in many customers including in Korea and a few other places. And we already talked about PADS as perhaps a twist on a derivative of that structure down the road. So it's really nothing new and it's not a concentration issue. It's just a fact that we have products and they are similar that's spread across multiple OEMs. And in programs where again, we try to price ourselves where the customer is willing to pay a premium.

So I was just specifically asking about that. And Doug, I can take it by your comment that you didn't have any 10% customers this quarter?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Terence Whalen with Citi.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: This question is a little bit of a higher level question on the wireline business. If I think about 1.5 years back to your Analyst Day, that was sort of the commencement of what, at that point, was a 3-year growth runway for the wireless business, including the ASIC business doubling, and the optical business enjoying a transition to proprietary from standard. From that sort of high-level construct that we developed 1.5 years ago, can you perhaps give us an update on where we are in that growth cycle? And what new developments have sort of come up over the past 1.5 years to give you confidence in the continued growth of the ASIC business and the continued margin improvement in optical?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: That's a very good question, and looking back top-down, that the wired infrastructure business is still very much -- the trend of it, it's still very much in line with what we laid out in terms of a strategic plan 2, 3 years ago. It continues to be tracking up, in our view, and not perfectly as we like to see it, but one never gets it perfectly in a sense that our optical business is probably growing faster in some ways than our ASIC business. But having said that, on a total combined basis, still trending along the same direction. What's also interesting is, and we said that 2, 3 years ago, we see this product, this segment to expand fairly fast in gross margin, product margin, gross margin. And that's exactly also what's happening. Revenue may not be as fast as we like it to be, but not far from that. But our gross margin is certainly running higher than our expectations 3 years ago. So overall net-net, we're pretty pleased with it.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: Okay, terrific. And then my follow-up question is Avago is recently named along with QUALCOMM and Broadcom by Huawei for a longer-term supply contract. Perhaps you can sort of address what your prospects are in the Chinese smartphone market, particularly given the OEM landscape you see and particularly given the standards that they use among them, TD-LTE versus FD-LTE?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: Well, yes, it's well, obviously, we have, I mean, Huawei, ZTE and a few other Chinese phone makers are very good customers of Avago. And in some of those key customers, we provide components in the smart -- as you correctly hit on, smartphones. Components for the smartphones, as well as I should add in the case of Huawei and ZTE data cards. These 2 have been some of the -- among the 2 largest producers of data cards in the world and we provide them with specific components that are very, very high performance, very low power, which is what they like. And that's how we developed that strategic relationship for our products. And we continue to have that. And I won't exactly say that they're a huge, huge customer. Though to us, they are very important customers and strategic and the components we provide meets their performance specs very well. Again, same old strategy. Do we see ourselves as a mass-market producer in China of components in smartphones? No. We're not. We don't for instance, produce in 2G EDGE market at all, but we obviously, are producing in the UMTS, CDMA markets where China does play within Chinese markets. And we have also product offerings into TD, TD-LTE and to some extent TD-SCDMA. And those are the areas where we tend to play in the high-end phones, smart phones where they produce them. But those are not necessarily the high volume that sells in China. Those are more the high-end niche markets, smartphone markets either in China or exported by people at Huawei, ZTE into more developed countries.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012

Our gross margin, as we always say, has been expanding year after year. Quietly but expanding and of course, overlaying it quarter by quarter. We have ups and downs based on seasonality and unique situations of each product. And you all know that, I know, industrial has the highest product margins. Wired infrastructure is somewhat above average now. And wireless is somewhat below average. And the mix of it comes out very interesting and with Q1 mix the way it is, yes, it is not as Doug pointed out in his remarks, a quarter where we expect our gross margin to be stupendously glamorous. And yet we come out mind you, okay, 15.6%. So if industrial starts snapping back or recovering, do we expect gross margin to be at a different plateau? Yes. We say that every year. And every year it comes in at different level plateau. It just happens a bit differently as we go through a quarter of the year.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext: But JoAnne, I'll remind you. Our long-term model was non-GAAP gross margin 50% to 53%. We're not changing that at this point. That's still the long-term model.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug for reminding me. Right. But that's -- but your point is saying it's -- it needs a reflection of phenomenon that year-on-year, we tend to improve our gross margin 100, 150 basis points or 100 or 200 basis points a year. Not the same every year, and we still maintain that model, 100, 150. Don't let any one particular quarter lead you too far astray because it just ends up above them. But the thing we find ourselves very pleased about is even in Q1's revenue mix, which is not entirely favorable for margin, we do manage to come in at a level that is obviously, at a different plane from say, what it was if the same mix were in place 2 years ago. That is for sure. Then coming back to your first part of the question on industrial revenue and mix and all that, the bottom line is, we do not believe we lost market share at all. Now as you know in industrial, most of our revenue goes in -- are sold through distributors. To be precise, 80% of the revenue in industrial goes through distributors. And all the others item I want to point out is Q1, our revenue, which the shipped in, most of that's shipped in to distributors, dropped sequentially, almost 30% to be precise 29%. Yet our resale out of distributors dropped only 10%. So you would say the gap here, the difference here is all about reducing general inventory in the pipeline. 
And I might add, we did similar, the remaining 20% industrial, we have a similar positioning, the similar phenomenon happening on the distribution sitting in our direct industrial OEM customers. So most of it, not all, but most of that reduction, sequential reduction is coming out of inventory. But I should add, resale did drop 10%. So there was a general weakening of overall industrial demand from our perspective. That resale as we pointed out, and I'd like to, and obviously emphasize that in the context of this question, we have now seen it flatten and in the sense that we have about almost less or almost 1 month since the end of last quarter, it's more than flattened since Chinese New year. It has picked up slightly as Doug said, flat to up slightly.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2012
componenttext:
Right. Okay. It is, in fact, it the story of our life in terms of model. It's a very good representation. What it is, is FBAR is not used everywhere just because it provides much better, much differentiated selectivity performance for reception of signals. The only thing is it's priced higher. And so a lot of people don't -- a lot 
of old phone OEMs chose not to use it if their performance is not that critical causes and they trade it off by using SAW filters instead of FBAR. But where they like the performance and they like the power FBAR produces -- generally it consumes less power and the trend seems to hit it that way. And the phone maker can afford it, they use FBAR. Now there are some bands, some spectrum or wireless spectrum that makes it very important to use FBAR because the modulation schemes and the signals makes it very hot to use to allow SAW to perform well and one example is CDMA. The CDMA bands prefer to use FBAR just to get a minimum level of performance. Then in 3G, UMTS, certain bands like Band 2 also like well, in fact, require the use of FBAR. Then we start going to LTE, and as we move to LTE phones, LTE spectrum tend to be more tricky. And more than LTE spectrum are scattered all over the map in terms of whatever is available, especially in North America, they inserted LTE. And one example is, for instance, Verizon LTE, which is running at about 700 megahertz as you know. The Verizon LTE fits next to the public safety radio band, okay? And so it's important you don't -- one doesn't crossover to the other. And so selectivity of signals become important. You don't want crosstalk interference and therefore, using FBAR becomes more and more critical when you want to operate in the spectrum at a band next to a public band. And about as important, another example is in the case of -- as you all know, that occurred that example of LightSquared where there's interference with the world GPS system. Now if world GPS uses filters like FBAR, you can keep the signals up. So that where FBAR comes into very, very good use. And when you start using complex phones, smartphones for LTE, which have to be interoperable with 3G and 2G you get more and more bands stuck in together with Wi-Fi, you have a problem of what I call coexistence, which means interference of signals that operate very dense, very close to each other. Then you want to use FBAR. So getting phones more complicated, as they become smarter, they run in more bands, you start to need to use FBAR. So that's in a summary fashion, a long answer to your basic question, which is, is the trend heading our direction in FBAR and my question is, yes, absolutely. As you go into LTE more and more, the tendency to use FBAR becomes much higher.

componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. Good afternoon, everyone. Now we're going to start today by reviewing our recent end market business highlights, then Doug will provide summary of our second quarter financial results.
Revenue for Q2 fiscal year was $577 million, which was at the midpoint of our guidance. This was up 2.5% from Q1, but only up 3% from the same quarter last year. While results for our wireless and wireline markets were in line with expectations, our industrial revenue came in stronger than we had forecasted. Nevertheless, year-on-year, industrial was still down 26%. In contrast, however, wireless was up a strong 26%. 
As we also discussed in our last earnings call, we saw stabilization of industrial market as we entered Q2. However, as March came around, we started to experience a strong recovery in China. As I sit here today, we believe the industrial market is now on a solid path to recovery with Asia Pacific leading the way, but Europe and North America continuing to lag somewhat.
Let me now provide more color on our end markets, starting with wireless. To put in perspective, the first half of our fiscal year would typically experience seasonal weakness. However, as you may recall, it was not that way in Q1 this fiscal year. In fact, wireless revenue in Q1 was robust as we ramp up volume in a major OEM. This held up in Q2 despite normal seasonality in the broader industry. As a result, year-on-year, our wireless revenue grew a strong 26% and in total, revenue from wireless represented 44% of our second fiscal quarter revenues of which approximately 3/4 were derived from smartphones.
Now looking to Q3, we do see 2 near-term challenges to sequential seasonal growth. The first is a constraint on availability of QUALCOMM's next-generation 28-nanometer fully integrated LTE baseband where we have been very well positioned. This constraint will limit our revenue for multiple OEMs this quarter and could negatively impact growth in Q3 by approximately $8 million to $12 million. 
Secondly, the ramp we enjoyed in Q1 and sustained in Q2 in a major OEM is now facing a significant product transition and could impact our Q3 wireless revenue by another $10 million to $15 million. Based on these 2 factors, we expect our wireless revenue to be flat, maybe slightly down in what would otherwise be a seasonally up quarter in Q3.
Having said all that, we expect shipments for the QUALCOMM's 28-nanometer baseband to reflect pent-up demand in our fiscal Q4. We also expect completion of the product transition and ramp of the next-generation product at that major OEM to drive fiscal Q4 wireless revenue growth again. And in fact, to prepare for this ramp in Q2, we invested approximately $40 million in process improvements and added capacity, and we plan to invest roughly another $45 million this quarter and reposition over $15 million of inventory ahead of this ramp to date.
Turning to industrial and automotive target markets. Revenue here accounted for 22% of Q2 revenues and grew 9% sequentially. But I must emphasize, this level is still 26% below the same quarter a year ago. As I mentioned earlier during the quarter, we saw the industrial market start to recover. China demand return in Q2, up over 25% quarter-on-quarter growth, and we expect the momentum to continue in Q3 driven by resumption of investment in power generation and distribution as well as for machine tools and factory automation. Spending in high-speed transportation has also resumed, though much of this spending appears to be benefiting largely indigenous industrial companies to date. 
Japan, North America and Europe have largely dependent on exports to emerging economies and are still in the very early stages of recovery due to a lag in their supply chains. As our OEM customers in these geographies recover, however, driven by China, we expect growth of our industrial revenue to accelerate to meeting sequentially in Q3. 
Moving on to wide infrastructure. Revenue here represented around 30% of Q2 revenues. As we expected, this revenue grew 4% sequentially, but a rather disappointing 5% from the quarter a year ago. While we continue to gain share in our service base ASICs going into data center switching, we're achieving this in a conservative demand environment for enterprise networking and carrier routing. 
Notwithstanding this rather flattish revenue, design wins were strong in Q2 as we continue to secure our next-generation programs in the enterprise for 40G, optical interconnect and more complex low-latency, low-power data center switches. We've also secured successfully design wins for next-generation core routing for 50G and 100G optical interconnects. But really what drives for short-term revenue is the conversion to 10G in networking and computing and should continue to drive sequential revenue growth low- to mid-single digits even in this uncertain environment.
Finally, revenue from consumer markets continue to be a small portion of our quarterly totals and represented only 5% of our Q2 revenues. This was a decline of 9% sequentially, flat from a year ago. Continuing this mode of harvesting our nonstrategic and mature products here, in consumer, we've decided to convert the business model of manufacturing and selling products to one of licensing designs and related IP, thus securing a future royalty stream instead of product sales.
So to sum up, in Q2, we grew 2% sequentially driven largely by industrial and automotive despite an uninspiring demand environment for wide infrastructure. For Q3, while we do not expect a typical seasonal uptick in wireless, we expect strong continuing industrial recovery to drive overall revenue growth of between 3% and 6% from Q2. As I mentioned earlier, we expect Q3 to be the transition into a strong revenue ramp in Q4 for our wireless business. Coupling this with continued recovery of industrial markets worldwide, we feel good about significant uptick in our Q4 consolidated revenue. 
Before I turn this call over to Doug, I would like to inform you of a recent material development. As you all know, we have been in litigation with TriQuint on several issues related to FBAR and BAW filters. We now have reached a settlement with TriQuint. Unfortunately, the terms of which are confidential between the 2 parties. One thing that I can tell you though is the settlement will have a favorable financial impact for Avago. 
With that, let me now turn the call over to Doug for a more detailed review of our second quarter 2012 financials.

componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Hock, and good afternoon, everyone. Before reviewing the second quarter fiscal 2012 financial results, I want to remind you that my comments today, as always, will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release that we issued today, and it's also available on our website at avagotech.com.
Avago Q2 revenue of $577 million increased 2.5% from last quarter and 3% versus the same quarter a year ago. This sequential increase was in line with our expectations, and as Hock reviewed, revenue from our industrial target market came in stronger than we expected. Revenue from our wired and wireless target market came in approximately as we expected. And then finally, for the consumer target market, revenue declined 9% sequentially, and this was a little bit worse than we expected.
In last quarter, we disclosed that Foxconn was a greater than 10% customer, and I want to let you know they continue to be one this quarter as well. Distribution resales during the quarter grew sequentially nearly double digits, while inventory at our distributors grew in the low-single digits. As a result of this, months of supply and distribution obviously declined. We remain encouraged by the trend in distribution resales we're seeing today.
Our Q2 gross margin was 51.1%, and this increased 50 basis points from last quarter and it was also in the upper half of our guided range. The positive gross margin result was helped by a favorable product mix from stronger industrial market revenue. 
So now turning to operating expenses. R&D expenses for Q2 increased by $1 million to $79 million. SG&A also increased by $1 million to $45 million. I'd like to point out that these spending increases were partially offset by spending reductions due to lower variable compensation accruals. As a percentage of sales, R&D remained at 14%, and SG&A remained at 8% of net revenues.
Income from operations for the quarter increased by $8 million sequentially to $171 million, and this represented 29.6% of net revenue. Compared to the $167 million for Q2 of last year, operational income increased by $4 million. Below the operating income line, we recorded a net gain of $3 million due to several factors, most notably from interest income as well as favorable foreign currency translations.
Taxes of $6 million for Q2 were $1 million higher than the prior quarter. Q2 net income of $168 million increased 8% from the prior quarter, and Q2 earnings per diluted share of $0.66 was $0.04 higher than Q1. Compared to Q2 of last year, net income was $3 million higher and for earnings per diluted share, it was $0.02 higher. And then just to summarize a little bit. The sequential increase in Q2 earnings was primarily attributed to higher gross margin and continued spending controls.
Our share-based compensation in Q2 was $13 million. The breakdown of this expense for Q2 includes $2 million in cost of goods sold, $5 million in R&D and $6 million in SG&A. In Q3, we anticipate share-based compensation will be approximately $15 million. And just a reminder, the company's definition of non-GAAP net income excludes share-based compensation expense. 
So now let me move to the balance sheet. Our days sales outstanding came in at 43 days. This was down 7 days from the prior quarter as we benefited from collections from shipments earlier in the quarter, the timing of Chinese New Year and the continued strong focus on collections.
Our inventory ended at $218 million, which was an increase of $25 million from Q1. Days on hand were 70 days, which increased 7 days from Q1. And as I stated in our last earnings call, we thought inventory would go up in Q2, which it did. This inventory growth is associated with higher revenue levels, builds to manage capacity as we head into a stronger Q4, as well as the purchase of wafers that enabled enhanced cost reductions from a specific supplier. 
We ended the quarter with a cash balance of $954 million, and we generated $211 million in operating cash flow. We spent $56 million in total on new capital equipment purchases. For Q3, we expect CapEx to be in the range of $63 million to $73 million. At the beginning of the year, I told you our CapEx was expected to be approximately $200 million for the fiscal year. I now expect it will come in higher than that as we are adding incremental FBAR filter capacity to support new business needs.
During the quarter, the company consumed $6 million in stock repurchases. We essentially paused our repurchases during most of the quarter due to the timing of the annual shareholder vote on the authorization. After the shareholder vote, our Board of Directors authorized the company to repurchase up to an additional $15 million of our ordinary shares. On March 30, 2012, we paid a quarterly cash dividend of $0.13 per ordinary share, and this consumed $32 million of cash. The dividend was raised by $0.01 from the prior quarter, and since the inception of our dividend program in Q1 of 2011, we have continued to increase our dividend each quarter. We also continue to evaluate potential strategic investments in acquisitions as another way of deploying cash to maximize the return to our shareholders.
So just to summarize my points regarding cash flow. Our Q2 cash level shows that our cash-generating capability continues to be strong despite higher cash outlays for capital equipment and increasing dividends for our shareholders. 
Now let me cover the balance of our non-GAAP guidance for the third quarter of fiscal 2012. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we do not intend to update this guidance. Revenue is expected to increase 3% to 6% sequentially from Q2. Gross margin is expected to be approximately 51.5%, plus or minus 75 basis points. Operating expenses are estimated to be approximately $129 million, the increase being driven by incremental R&D project spending. Interest and other is projected to be approximately $1 million. Taxes are forecasted to be approximately $7 million. And finally, the diluted share count forecast is for 254 million shares. 
That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, if you would, please open up the call for questions.

But from a duplexer point of view, you can now integrate duplexers. So every new band requires 1 duplexer. So duplexer will linearly scale up volume-wise as more bands are supported by any cellphone. So no surprise typically that they would be the first to bounce back on any increase in industrial infrastructure demand. The larger OEMs, multinational OEMs, I would say, as I indicated in my remarks, tend to have a much longer supply chain and would therefore lag behind those indigenous Chinese companies who probably are showing what I call the early indicators of a recovery in industrial demand over there.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 22, 2012
componenttext: A couple of questions if I can. Hock, first of all, when you look at the wireless business and you're talking about the bands, as you look at a phone today versus a phone in 6 months and a year from now, how many bands do you see being incorporated into some of these world phones? And then concurrently with that, as you look at the bands for the FBAR, I know it's very popular in Band 2, but what are the bands do you see strong demand for the FBAR technology? And then a couple follow-ons for Doug if I can.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 22, 2012
componenttext: Okay. To give you, and if you can forgive me for that, because we are in this huge forum, and I'd be happy to do it separately on a different occasion. But really, what we do see is with LTE coming in, the phones have to be 3G and 2G, 2.5G compatible as well. So the number of bands you're including in those world phones, we get over 10, very fast, over 10. If you want to have a world phone that roams in multiple continents, easily over 10, which puts in a lot of content. And in terms of FBAR, you're right. CDMA uses FBAR. Band 2 uses FBAR and 3G. And in LTE, more and more of those bands in LTE are using FBAR for no other reason than that some of these bands may be difficult, like Band 2, for signal reception. That's why you need FBAR for better performance. But as you also have more and more bands crowded on the antenna on the phone, they start to interfere with each other; the issue of what we call coexistence. And when you have coexistence, problem for reception, your way to solve it is to put in an FBAR filter, and that's it. Just like you hear about this harbinger issue with LightSquared, a way to solve it, simplistic minded, is put in an FBAR filter. You immediately solve it. Of course, there's a lot of legacy equipment that you have to go retrofit, which makes it impractical. But for new equipment, put in FBAR and you literally solve that problem.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 22, 2012
componenttext: Right. Phil Falcone never called you. But Hock, do you see 10 bands in phones by the end of this year?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 22, 2012

Some OEMs decide to run their phones where they do a phone for a particular local market or regional market. So they don't need to kind of make all that bands into one phone. There are some who puts all the bands into a common phone so that they use a single platform.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 22, 2012

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 22, 2012
componenttext: A couple here. Hock, you did talk about LTE and that is coming on board and it requires both filters and PAs. A little -- what I'm wondering though is both Skyworks and RF Micro have made no secret of the fact that their high-efficiency amplifiers, which are relatively new, are winning a lot of sockets. We've been out beating bushes, and they haven't seen a lot of competition. I know Avago's got stuff on the drawing boards. Do you expect to be competitive in that area before the end of the year? And then secondly, with regard to LTEs since most of these are going into LTE sockets, the majority I guess of LTE has been in 13 and 17 bands in the U.S. because of Verizon and AT&T. And given the frequencies of those, I think majority of the technology solving those band issues have been SAW, temp comp SAW given the size that the ball would be for that, how expensive would be. Is a lot of the growth that you're seeing in FBAR mostly in the traditional bands? Or are you -- do you feel like you're winning as much or more of your share in these new LTE bands given the, I won't say disadvantage, but the parity that SAW would have  cost in the lower bands? And then I have a couple for Doug, please.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 22, 2012
componenttext: Okay. Well, to answer your first part of the question, I really don't comment on my competitors' offerings, nor do we talk much about market share. If you noticed, Ed, really. My competitors, I'm sure, do talk about it. That's their business model. That's their prerogative. We chose not to talk about it. We do have competitive offerings, and that's probably as far as I would go. We do have very competitive offerings. As far as FBAR is concerned, yes, that is increasing demand for FBAR. And a big part of it, as I mentioned, is not just new bands that do require -- and that are difficult for single modulation to transmit and that because of that require FBAR versus SAW. I think that may happen less of an issue as much as the bigger issue. And you could see that in Europe in band -- in Band 7, Band 20 and 7, where it is an FBAR kind of requirement for that band. But more than that is, as you put in LTE and still have to run 3G, UMTS that is and 2G, you basically have so much signals of various types going through your phone. You have, as I mentioned again, the issue of interference or coexistence. And once you have that, the easiest way, the best way to solve it is to start putting in more and more FBAR. And that's basically the bottom line to it. And not to mention the ancillary benefits that FBAR does stand to bring to the equation. I know they don't cost cheaper, but it brings typically much lower power and very often, much smaller dimension, which in cellphones that are getting very, very crowded with other content becomes extremely important. So there are multiple reasons why FBAR get used, the price and other things.

componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. Good afternoon, everyone. We're going to start today by reviewing recent end market highlights, and then Doug will provide a summary of third quarter financials.
Now, revenue for our Q3 fiscal year was $606 million, which was slightly above the midpoint of our guidance, and this represented an increase of 5% from last quarter but an increase of less than 1% from the same quarter a year ago. 
Now during this Q3, industrial was strong, driven by continued recovery in Asia. Wired infrastructure was modestly up. Enterprise was flat, but we were helped by strength from service providers. Wireless was down, below our estimate at the beginning of the quarter, because of product transition at one of our major OEMs.
Now looking into next quarter, Q4, however, we no longer have the revenue contribution, if you recall, from a consumer navigation product, which represented approximately 7% of Q3 revenues. 
In this Q4, we foresee, we forecast industrial and wired infrastructure to be down, which leads us really with only one cylinder running on turbocharge for Q4. I would like to point out, though, that the strength of this wireless will still enable us to grow modestly quarter-over-quarter in Q4. And if I look at our 3 primary target markets, excluding consumer business, our total revenue is actually expected to increase in the mid- to high single-digits in Q4 on an apple-to-apple comparison of, no pun intended, compared to Q3.
Let me provide more color on each of our end markets, starting with wireless. Second half of our fiscal year is playing out pretty much as we expected. Revenue from wireless declined 5% sequentially and represented 40% of our third fiscal quarter revenue. As you may recall during my last earnings call in May, I pointed out 2 near-term challenges to our wireless business in the third quarter, namely the supply constraint of Qualcomm's 28-nanometers LTE baseband chipset as well as a product transition cycle at one of our large OEM customers. These 2 near-term challenges were the main reasons wireless revenues were down sequentially in the quarter that is normally a seasonally strong quarter.
I also noted on our last call that we expected wireless to be very strong in Q4. As many of you know, we are very well positioned in Qualcomm's 28-nanometer LTE platform. The 28-nanometer supply has made some progress, as we have seen, as small supply becomes available to some of our -- many of our customers, OEM customers. Consequentially, we are now seeing demand for our RF front-end solutions associated with this platform accelerating with certain OEMs today.
In addition, we're now seeing the full benefit of the product transition at one of our large OEM customers. Our content at this OEM and volumes are also up significantly. And as a result, we expect wireless revenue to be up in the range of 20% to 30% in Q4 compared to Q3.
Moving on to wired infrastructure. Revenue here represented 29% of Q3 revenues. Wired was in line with our expectation at the beginning of this quarter, with revenues up 3% sequentially. We benefited from double-digit growth in 2.5G and 5G power optics used in core routing applications as we ship into major programs at service providers in North America and China. 
Demand for ASICs remained, and looking into Q4, we expect sequential growth in ASICs because of strength in data center switching. However, reflecting what we perceive as a hiatus in the implementation of core routing programs, we expect to see a temporary decline in our power optics, primarily tied to one of our large OEM customers. As a result, we expect overall revenue from wired infrastructure to decline high single-digits on a percentage basis for the fourth quarter.
Finally, turning to industrial and automotive markets. Revenue from this target market accounted for 24% of our Q3 net revenue. Net sales grew 19% sequentially, which was slightly better than our expectations, while worldwide resales were up again, growing 5%, and gave us confidence the recovery we saw last quarter is continuing.
As we expected, demand from China was strong. We believe government stimulus programs and a looser credit environment drove our distribution partners and local Chinese customers to more aggressively take product in the quarter. However, revenues remains -- still remains 17% below the same quarter a year ago. 
So China is recovering. Japan and North America were flat, but Europe remained a weak spot. Even though we expect resales to grow in Q4, given the robust revenue uptake, particular ship -- particularly our ship into distributors we saw in Q3 and a relatively soft demand environment outside China, we expect industrial revenue to decline mid- to high single-digits in Q4.
Revenue from consumer as note -- as a final note, revenue from consumer and computing peripheral markets represented, as I mentioned earlier, about 7% of our Q3 revenues, reflecting really last time buys resulting from our transition to a royalty business model in consumer navigation. And in this market, sales grew 47% sequentially from the prior quarter and grew 33% from the same quarter a year ago.
So in summary, as we mentioned, we grew 5% sequentially in the third quarter, driven largely by strength in industrial. For this fourth quarter, we forecast overall revenue growth of between 0 to 3% from Q3 caused the by the sharp fall-off in revenue from a consumer navigation business and, frankly, on certain demand in carrier routing, despite what is a very strong revenue ramp for wireless business. 
And again, to reiterate, without looking in revenue from our consumer business, revenue growth from our 3 primary targets will be projected to be up mid- to single-digit -- mid- to high single-digits.
With that, let me turn the call over to Doug for a more detailed review of our third quarter 2012 financials.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Hock. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining our call this quarter. Before reviewing the third quarter fiscal 2012 financial results, I want to remind you that my comments today, as always, will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release that we issued today and is also available on our website at avagotech.com.
Revenue of $606 million in Q3 represents an increase of 5% from last quarter and an increase of 0.5% versus the same quarter a year ago. The sequential increase was in the upper half of our guidance for the quarter. Revenue from our industrial and consumer target markets were a little stronger than we expected. Revenue from our wired target market came in approximately as we expected. And then finally, revenue from our wireless target market came in slightly weaker than we expected.
And for the last 2 quarters, we've disclosed that Foxconn was a greater-than-10% customer, and they continued to be one again this quarter.
For the second consecutive quarter, distribution resales grew in the mid-single-digits. And as Hock described, the sequential growth of resales was primarily driven by strength in Asia, China in particular, while Europe remained weak.
Looking into Q4, we expect resales will continue to grow. During Q3, however, our inventory and distribution grew at a rate slightly greater than resales. Hence, we expect revenue into the distribution channel would decline somewhat in Q4. And then, just to remind you, the end market impacted the most significantly by distribution is our industrial and automotive target market.
Q3 gross margin was 51.2%, slightly below the midpoint of our guidance. This result was driven by a slightly negative product mix within the wireless target market as well as greater revenue from our lower-margin consumer target market.
So turning to operating expenses. R&D expenses for Q3 increased by $4 million to $83 million, while SG&A decreased by $4 million to $41 million, which left operating expenses unchanged at $124 million from last quarter. 
OpEx came in $5 million lower than our expectation a quarter ago, due to the timing of certain R&D programs as well as lower litigation spending. As a percentage of sales, R&D remained at 14%, and SG&A decreased to 7% of net revenue.
Income from operations for the quarter increased by $15 million sequentially to $186 million, and this represented 31% of net revenue. Compared to the $177 million for Q3 of last year, income from operations increased by $9 million. 
We recorded a net gain of $1 million in interest and other, primarily due to the interest on our cash balances. Taxes of $5 million for Q3 were $1 million lower than the prior quarter. The decrease was related to the jurisdictional mix of income.
Q3 net income of $182 million increased 8% from the prior quarter, and Q3 earnings per diluted share of $0.72 was $0.06 higher than Q2. Compared to Q3 of last year, net income was $6 million higher, and for earnings per diluted share, it was $0.04 higher. Earnings were higher versus the prior year, primarily due to lower spending. And the sequential increase in Q3 earnings was primarily attributed to the higher revenue.
Our share-based compensation in Q3 was $15 million. The breakdown of the expense for Q3 includes $1 million in cost of goods sold, $6 million in R&D and $8 million in SG&A. In Q4, I anticipate share-based compensation will again be approximately $15 million. And just to remind you, the company's definition of non-GAAP net income excludes share-based compensation expense.
So now let me move to the balance sheet. Our days sales outstanding came in at 50 days. This was up 7 days from the prior quarter. The increase was due to the linearity of revenue within the quarter. 
Our inventory ended at $216 million, which was a slight decrease of $2 million from last quarter. Days on hand came in at 66 days, which decreased 4 days from Q2. We ended the quarter with a cash balance of $973 million, and we generated $128 million in operational cash flow.
We spent $65 million on new capital equipment. And for next quarter, Q4, I expect CapEx will be in the range of $70 million to $80 million. The increase is primarily due to incremental FBAR filter capacity to support growing customer demand.
During the quarter, we consumed $15 million on stock repurchases. And on June 29 of 2012, we paid a quarterly cash dividend of $0.15 per ordinary share, which consumed $37 million of cash. This dividend was raised by $0.02 from the prior quarter. Since the inception of our dividend program in Q1 of 2011, we have continued to increase our dividend each quarter.
We also continue to evaluate potential strategic investments and acquisitions as another way of deploying cash to maximize the return to shareholders. However, as a matter of policy, we do not comment on rumors or speculations regarding any specific acquisition targets or strategy.
Now let me cover the balance of our non-GAAP guidance for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2012.  This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions, and we do not intend to update this guidance. 
Revenue is expected to be in a range of flat to up 3% over Q3, driven primarily by growth in wireless. Gross margin is expected to be approximately 51.25%, plus or minus 75 basis points. Operating expenses are estimated to stay flat at $124 million. Interest and other is projected to be approximately $1 million. Taxes are forecasted to be approximately $8 million. Taxes are slightly up due to the timing of certain discrete tax items. And finally, the diluted share count forecast is for 253 million shares. 
That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, would you please open up the call for questions?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Well, interesting question. Let me try to address that. But to answer -- but to jump straight on, yes, we have a fairly broad customer base in wireless. But we also sell through tier-3 white-box phone manufacturers in China on a case-by-case basis, depending on the programs and when and the specific technologies they are using. So we are pretty broad-based. But you're right in that respect, it's a very interesting tiered market now. Very, very much a question of picking winners and losers, so to speak, in terms of OEMs. And we try to cover the full range with the products we have and the technology we have. And some customers really appreciate and are willing to, obviously, subscribe to our business model of very-high-performance RF components be -- and particularly our FBAR components. Overall, we -- but to address your question on the pattern of behavior, forecasting is always hard, but let me try to do that, draw some reference point by looking back to last year, the last 12 months. Typical seasonality is end of the year, headed towards back-to-school and Christmas, so strong typical seasonality, up. And the continuing strong seasonality in Q4. And by that, I usually mean 10%, perhaps sequentially, maybe then mid- to high single-digits in Q4. Then Q1 will show a -- on the next Q1 following the fall will show a sharp drop and could be mid- to high single -- to even 10% drop. And Q2, from Q2, will be kind of flat from Q1, and the cycle repeats itself. And that used to be the case, say, 2 years ago, 3 years ago. Comes last year, we see a significant change in the pattern, in this whole pattern, and part of it is related to what you're pointing out, the way the market has segmented itself among OEMs and based on how those OEMs launch new products and the timing in which it launches.
