As Doug said, we're going to double our capacity over the next -- less than the next 12 months. By middle of next year, we expect to have doubled FBAR capacity. We have a year before that, which is this year. And we expect to fully utilize it based on demand we are seeing out there. So strategically, we think that's exactly the right thing to do. It is also a differentiated technology, which is exactly in line with our business model of providing that kind of products. In turning to one -- the point you have, gallium arsenide, we did announce about 2, 3 quarters ago -- 3 quarters ago, investment in a relatively small capacity in gallium arsenide HPD used for power amplifiers. In fact, they are used in the power -- used to produce power amplifiers we sell today. Most of -- many of which are in conjunction in front-end modules, we have our FBAR, but some discrete, like the multimode power amplifier we have been selling this year. To -- in answer to your question is there differentiation? There always is generation to -- in generation, based on mainly design, some process, but mainly design. But unlike FBAR, I do want to say to you, it's hard to make that difference a sustainable differentiation on power amplifiers, which is why our focus is really on FBAR. The reason we build that small capacity on gallium arsenide is that most of our requirements on gallium arsenide is right now outsourced through our foundry in Taiwan. We figured in the fall, second sourcing, security of supply purposes as well as to have the ability to tweak process, improve performance of some of the power amplifiers as we need to. That -- it's good to have a small fab in-house to be able to do that so that we can port that process over to our foundry. But most, by far, 75% of our demand, 80% of our requirements in power amplifiers will come from our foundry. And also we'll -- yes. that's about it.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Okay. Next question is about RF content in the handsets. You indicated that you're -- going into the next quarter, you're going to see a significant increase in the RF content. How much headroom do you have going forward? Do you think that are we -- your content is going to increase? Or do you see that letting out at some point of time?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: First and foremost, I should be -- I apologize, if I may have -- given you a wrong impression. Content does, in today's market on smartphones especially, will likely vary from generation to generation. And it would likely, given the trend or where the technology and industry is headed, will typically -- RF content in every smartphone will keep increasing. Why? Because of the fact that you increase the amount of functionality and capability of roaming with the same handset as you move up from 2G, 3G and now LTE. So there is that underlying trend. Having said that, depending on the phone manufacturer, OEM, a particular phone may have -- may not have as much content as phone from another OEM, simply because it depends on the carrier, it depends on the region and the band and the performance they want to make this phone. So it doesn't necessarily mean that it's a monotonic increase across the board as time passes on all phones. It depends on what particular phone program you're -- or we are designing and what particular OEM. So it does vary. It's -- my sense is that with among some of our tier-1 guys, customers, we tend to address the very-high-end smartphones which tends to lend itself to a lot of functionality, a lot of ability to support multiple bands. And because of that, the opportunity for us to increase our content keeps growing.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Our next question comes from Christopher Danely, JPMorgan.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Hock, can you just maybe run down your 3 big end markets and also the geos? And how do you think things are playing out here? Where are you more worried? And how do you expect a recovery to look in some of the troubled end markets and geos out there?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Well, yes, let's start with wireless. I mean, our perception on the wireless side is -- on the high-end -- on the smartphone side, things to continue to look fairly strong, fairly robust.  Part of it may be a matter of -- fortunately, on our side, being as well as a strategic purpose in addressing more winners than losers in the smartphone area. And secondly, on those -- some of those OEMs we're addressing, our business model requires us to pretty much try to differentiate our products, differentiate in the sense of better performance, and better performance typically means more content in many cases. And we have the advantage of getting that in, especially in a situation where more -- in many OEMs, in certain bands in LTE, where the use of FBAR is increasing for duplexing for filtering. And so all that is good in the direction we're headed. But we -- as far as we see, that handset -- high-end handset market is still fairly robust. Turning to wired infrastructure, as I touched on lightly earlier, we see enterprise side, which is the large part of our wired infrastructure business, which is enterprise networking, enterprise computing and storage. We see that the market has been rather -- has been very flat, almost I use the word sluggish and flat. And that's been that way now for about 3, 6, almost -- at least 3 months, maybe even 6 months. It's not down, but it's not up either. And our overlay on it is a sector of the business we address, which is carrier routing from service providers, and that's a lumpy kind of business. We're seeing good strength or -- very a lot of strength on it, in investment in it in Q3. A big part of it is going into core routing, been using a lot of backhaul for wireless infrastructure investments, a big part of it. So we see that investment coming in chunks. And we sell a lot of content when that happens at very high margin, products of our fiber optics. And then on the end -- and then so -- but that's pretty much what we continue to see in wired infrastructure. In industrial, things have gone down a lot. Things did go down a lot late last calendar year and Q1, Q2 of our fiscal year this year and have since we have seen been on the recovery. The recovery has been very limited. As I said, we're very focused in Asia, and also been relatively slow in a sense that it's mid-single-digits if you look at it worldwide, and really what we see is China is probably growing faster than that, in maybe around 10% level. But the rest of the world is kind of flattish. So it's kind of been pulled up. When you average it out, it's mid-single-digits. And we cannot see that continuing for the next 6 months or so. Beyond that, I don't really know. But that's our view of the world as we see it right now.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Great. And then just a quick follow-up for Doug, what should we be thinking about for tax for the next fiscal year?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Chris, the way to think about tax here, our effective tax rate is 4% to 5% on a run-rate basis. And quarter-by-quarter, you get some lumpiness depending on when tax returns get filed or different -- you do different true-ups each quarter, depending on what's happening in each jurisdiction. But think of it as a 4% to 5% ETR.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Romit Shah from Nomura.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: You mentioned that, Hock, industrial would be down in October, I believe, around 5%, 6%. A lot of the analog guys, like Maxim, TI and Linear, in July, they guided industrial flat to up. I'm just curious if August booking trends in industrial, do they weaken relative to July? Or do you see something unique in your mix?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: No, no, no. Let me clarify. Sorry, maybe I wasn't clear enough. As you know, Romit, we -- most of our industrial go through distributors, whether it be Europe -- most of it, not all, but China, Japan or the United States or North America go through distributors, and we recognize revenue on a ship-in basis through distributors. On a resale basis from distributors as well as direct OEM business we sell to certain large industrial OEMs, the revenues -- resale, I should say, has been steadily recovering. As I say, worldwide, we see it around mid-single-digits for the last couple of quarters. So we're steadily recovering. Now a lot of that recovery comes from China, where we see resale actual consumption by OEM customers in China, industrial OEM customers, actually growing close to double single -- double-digits, 10%, sometime -- earlier on, it was even faster, it's kind of slowed down a bit. But it's still pretty okay. The rest of the world, be they North America, Europe, it's pretty flat. Even Europe was down -- has been down. Japan and U.S. has been pretty flat. So you average it out, mid-single-digits. And that's what we saw. What we saw last quarter, July quarter, was fairly -- was a continued recovery in industrial, especially in China. What we did was we replenished a lot of inventory, not distributors. And that's why when resale was growing last quarter, industrial resale was growing mid-single digits, we were growing double -- in the mid-teens. On a ship-in basis, what we're also saying, therefore, in Q4 is we're pulling back on that, and actually we'll lightly burn inventory because of what we are foreseeing is resale in industrial will continue mid-single-digits in our October quarter, Q4. But our ship-in to distributors, which is how we recognize most of our industrial revenue, will actually be down.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. As a follow-up, I wanted to ask about acquisitions. You haven't been acquisitive in the past, but there are some reports that have been saying that Avago is looking to make a large deal in the -- in the, sorry in the industrial market. Can you at least, Hock, comment on your acquisition strategy? And in this environment where the end markets don't seem to be bailing anyone out, are you more inclined to do a deal?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Romit, this is Doug. I'm going to take that one. Romit, we always look at a lot of stuff.  We have over our history. We'll continue to do so. I don't think that's changed, necessarily. And we're not going to comment on any specific acquisition activity or targets.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vijay Rakesh of Sterne Agee.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Just on the wireless side, good work with the up 25% on the wireless side. I was just wondering when you look at your FBAR, you mentioned your capacity will increase -- will double here and double again next year. Do you see any advantage in bundling your PA with your FBAR for the OEMs?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: So let me just clarify one thing, Vijay, we're doubling capacity between kind of where we were 6 months ago to where we'll be mid-next year. It's not doubling and then doubling, necessarily. Although it may.  We haven't made that decision yet. And then I'll let Hock take the second part of your question.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Would you mind repeating the second part of your question, Vijay?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Yes. I was wondering, is there an advantage where -- in bundling your power amplifier with your FBAR for the handset OEM? Do you see upside from the PA business as well as you leverage your FBAR side?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: It's -- well, there are a couple of advantages. Most notably of which is, obviously, when you bundle -- when I say bundle, let me be clear about clarification.  We don't sell 2 discrete elements together. If we do, it certainly is coincidental more than preplanned. Because the customer, the OEM customer can design and have a duplexer, which is what an FBAR is, quite differently and laying it out there from designing in a power amplifier in that discrete element. What we do is many customers in architecting their circuit of their handsets would find it beneficial, and we totally agree. We find it beneficial that you put a power amplifier and a duplexer on the same -- of handling the same spectrum, the same band, in a single package.  They call it a front-end module. And it gives a lot of flexibility in design. We'd like to believe by matching the duplexer with a power amplifier ourselves, we optimize yield by optimize performance itself. And of course, for us, it's increased content. It doesn't necessarily improve our gross margin -- operating margin. In fact, usually it doesn't, as opposed to selling discrete FBAR. But it definitely increase the content, and it definitely, in our minds, improve design flexibility for the OEM customer.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Got it. And then just to follow up here, not to be myopic, but when you look at your gross margins and not beating a dead horse either, you have some headwinds here, right? I mean, your industrial is weak and your FBAR is -- wireless, you're just bringing in-house. As you look out a couple of quarters when you see a recovery in industrial and probably some of the wireless in-house, where do you see your gross margins move?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Yes, Vijay, I'm not going to give gross margin guidance more than one quarter at a time. Our business model hasn't changed. Our medium- to long-term business model is gross margin between 50% and 53%, we're not changing that. There's ups and downs each quarter, and I'll talk to you about that each quarter.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brendan Furlong of Miller Tabak.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Just a couple of loose ends more than anything else, here. On the consumer side, the roughly $10 million, $11 million for next quarter, a little bit higher than I would have thought. Is there some end-of-life stuff left in there? And is the run rate for that on a go-forward basis more in the like $5 million, $6 million, $7 million type of level?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Yes. There's a couple of million dollars that carry over in there, Brendan, things that are there in Q4 that will go away. I would expect this to be below $10 million on a steady-state basis as we get out of the current quarter in front of us.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then, I guess on the OpEx, came in nicely below, and the guidance looks pretty decent. But how should we directionally or whatever way you want to couch it think about OpEx into fiscal '13?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: The way to think about OpEx here is we have a business model that we invest to. We want R&D as a percent of revenue to be around 14%. So as revenue goes up, we'll tend to spend more. As revenue goes down, we may spend a little bit less. SG&A is around 7%. I'm pretty pleased that we've gotten it down to 7%. We're not going to let that tick back up. But that steady-state investment in R&D is required to keep the business growing the way we want it to grow long term, so it's not going to change too much from that.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Our next question comes from JoAnne Feeney, Longbow Research.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: So could you perhaps give us a breakdown on your industrial exposure geographically?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: You want to take that, Hock?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Geographically?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: You're asking region by region...

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Yes, Europe versus Asia versus North America.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Oh, roughly industrial? Oh, that's a tough one. Let me think, roughly, I would say yes, it's -- this is where we ship revenue, not necessarily where we design and it gets transferred to Asia to be built. I would say it's interesting in that regard, it's probably about -- Europe, Asia is probably around the same amount, and they probably comprise 60% between the 2 of them. And Japan and North America take the other 40%. So you may say 30%, 30%, 20%, 20%.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Perfect. And then could you give us a breakdown between the industrial and the automotive within that category?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Our automotive is really very small. It's very, very small. Of the total industrial, our automotive is probably about -- less than 10%.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: It's less than 10%, JoAnne.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Okay, great. And then back to industrial for just a second. So inventories climbed as your shipping exceeded resales.  Was that a fairly constant pattern over the course of the quarter? How were things at the beginning of the quarter versus the end of the quarter in that regard?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: It was relatively constant. Well, it comes in spurts. Beginning quarter was pretty strong, slowed down middle quarter and restarted again by the end of the quarter.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Are you referring to resales, Hock, or ship-in?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Ship-in.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Ship-in, JoAnne.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Ship-ins.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: And were resales fairly, then...

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: It tends to follow resale. We have a little lag. And you know how distributors are like.  They see a strong resale, they jump at it, and we rush. So there's a lag.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Okay. And then you were talking earlier about the discrete parts you sell versus the integrated FEMs and then FBAR versus PA. Do you happen to have a split you could give us between the revenues you derive from discrete parts versus from the integrated FEM?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Not with me right now, and I'm very loath to give it to you, because it varies every -- it varies a lot, and it fluctuates because every -- just about every OEM handset maker has a different architecture. And it depends on mix in each OEM, and that dictates the mix in our product.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: So it sounds like that varies, then, pretty significantly, even among your top 2 customers?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: No comment.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Yes, It varies a lot, JoAnne.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Okay. And then finally, if I could sneak one more in, you talked in the past about some traction with the China smartphone makers. I'm wondering if you could give us an update on how that's going?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Well, we continue to have pretty good traction in -- among the Chinese white-box guys. And data card manufacturers too, I may add. Because as you know, both Huawei and ZTE are among the largest 2 data card manufacturers in the world. And they also make smartphones. And we have pretty good traction with pretty much all of them as well as small tier-1 -- tier-2 guys, like Lenovo and a bunch of other names. It's just the strength of our sales organization in China that enable us to keep sustaining that business.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Lipacis, Jefferies.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Do you guys have a sense of what percentage of LTE phones or designs that are out there that you're seeing the FBAR filter penetrate?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: No, I don't have the answer. It's very hard -- again, it's a very hard question to answer, because not every LTE phone would use FBAR. First of all, it depends on the bands. Certain bands are more harder for signals to receive, which is what a lot of the FBAR filters do. And so it tends to favor the use of FBAR. But then at the end of the day, depending on the OEM manufacturer, how much -- how important is it to them strategically philosophically that they want superb performance?  And because buying an FBAR will require them to pay a premium, typically. So they may choose not to. So it gets rather subjective on what -- who uses FBAR versus who doesn't.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Yes, I understand that it's a function of the OEMs. I was wondering if your own market research suggested, are we talking -- if you have a view like, is this -- are you talking like 10% of the LTE market? Or a lot more than that, where you think you likely have the opportunity to tackle?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: I give you one. At the risk of sounding a bit hype-ish about our business model, if you sit here right now this -- last quarter or this quarter -- last quarter, I'll probably say LTE phones using FBAR could be 20%. If you ask me a year ago, a year from now, I will probably say 50% -- 40%, 50%.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Our final question comes from the line of Ian Ing, Lazard Capital.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Just to follow up on the RF discussion. As OEMs build 3G and 4G world phones, I think we understand you've got nice opportunities with higher PA and filter content. But really how many OEMs eventually go to that model when you look at companies like Samsung?  So you got the big 2 doing different strategies there?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Well, it's a $10,000 question. I don't think we know who's going to architect their phones and which way. You're right, you have 2 that are on polar ends of how they do things, and everybody else probably fits partway in between.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Okay. And then, Hock, maybe just briefly on uncertain demand in carrier routing, trying to reconcile that with Cisco's comments, which were more positive in a tough environment. Is it lumpy orders and short lead times or some underlying softness here you think?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2012
componenttext: Carrier routing is always lumpy and very often very short lead times as far as equipment and even our fiber is concerned. See, our products go into a very specific area in carrier routing. We're not that much in edge routing. We are very much in the core routing side. So you're really talking about few OEM customers who do core routing. And just as few service providers who use those kind of throughput -- core routing throughput in their networks, especially in backhaul. So yes, it gets very lumpy, necessarily. But it's very substantial and very profitable but very lumpy. So you're right, I mean, you read -- even -- as you say, you read the Cisco remarks, it's hard to figure from that how it translates to our fiscal outlook. All I can tell you is what we saw last quarter, which was pretty good, and what we feel is likely to happen given how strong it is last quarter, in this current Q4.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Welcome to the Avago Technologies Limited Fourth Fiscal Quarter and Fiscal Year 2012 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introduction, I would like to turn the call over to Tom Krause, Vice President of Corporate Development. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Doug Bettinger, Chief Financial Officer of Avago Technologies.
After the market closed today, Avago distributed a press release and financial tables describing our financial performance for the fourth fiscal quarter and fiscal year 2012. If you did not receive a copy, you may obtain the information from the Investors section of Avago's website at www.avagotech.com. This conference call is being webcast live and a recording will be available via telephone playback for one week. It will also be archived in the Investors section of our website.
During the prepared comments section of this call, Hock and Doug will be providing details of our fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2012 results, background to our Q1 2013 outlook and some commentary regarding the business environment. We will take questions after the end of our prepared comments.
In addition to U.S. GAAP reporting, Avago reports certain financial measures on a non-GAAP basis. A reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the tables attached to today's press release. Comments made during today's call will primarily refer to our non-GAAP financial results. Please refer to our press release today and our recent filings with the SEC for information on the specific risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements made on this call. 
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Hock Tan. Hock?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. Good afternoon, everyone, we're going to start today by reviewing recent end market business highlights, and then Doug will provide a summary of our fourth quarter and fiscal 2012 financial results.
Revenue for Q4 fiscal year was $618 million, which was slightly above the midpoint of our guidance. This represented an increase of 2% from last quarter but a decrease of 1% from the same quarter a year ago. However, if we just look at our 3 primary target markets, revenue from those markets grew 8% sequentially on an apple-to-apple comparison basis. For the full fiscal year 2012, revenue was $2.4 billion, which represented an increase of 1% from fiscal 2011. Essentially here, a 20% increase in our wireless business was offset largely by a 23% decline in industrial revenues. Wired infrastructure remained relatively flat.
Back to Q4 results. Wireless was very strong, driven by simultaneous product ramps at 2 of our large smartphone OEM customers. While there was certain bright spots in wired infrastructure, wired revenue was down due to largely weak call routing spending with service providers. Industrial was also down below our estimate at the beginning of the quarter, here though is because our distribution partners reduced inventory levels. Looking forward to Q1, wireless demand continues to be strong. However, we expect that continued supply chain contraction in industrial and the continued hiatus in call routing spending will result in a sequential decline in revenues over all. Let me now provide more color on each of our end markets.
Starting with wireless. Revenue from wireless came in at the upper end of our expectations, growing 30% sequentially. This sequential strength was driven primarily by product ramps at 2 large OEM customers. I guess I will let you figure out who those are. We also benefited from seasonal demand from selected smartphone makers in China and Japan. And this particular strength resulted in a mix -- a shift, I should say, a mix shift in our revenue mix with wireless increasing to 51% of total revenue for Q4.
Looking at Q1 fiscal 2013. Follow-on demand from our 2 major smartphone OEM ramps remain strong. In addition, we're continuing to see demand from certain other smartphone OEMs as it's pretty normal at this time of the year, as they launch multiple high-end smartphone programs to compete against each other. The upping in demand is also helped a lot by the proliferation of LTE capability in these platforms, and the strength of our FBAR products offering, which now supports 15 LTE frequency bands, is supporting this very well. We, therefore, expect overall wireless revenue to be virtually flat in Q1 despite what would normally be a seasonally weaker quarter.
Stepping back here for a second. I'd like to add, we have, as a company, cumulatively invested, or are currently investing, approximately $300 million into putting in place additional FBAR capacity. We, in fact, from 2011 to the end of 2013, fiscal 2013, we expect to quadruple our FBAR capacity driven pretty much by our expectation of strong customer demand. The growth in FBAR, as a key point here, will improve our wireless gross margin going forward. 
Moving on to wired infrastructure. Revenues here came in slightly better than we expected at the beginning of the quarter, notwithstanding, revenue sequentially declined 8%. We did benefit from double-digit growth of our ASIC business shipping into data center switching. However, the pullback in our call routing business at one of our communications, OEM customers particularly, more than offset the strength in the ASIC business. And looking forward into Q1, we expect wired revenue to continue to decline around low -- high-single digits, low-double digits on a percentage basis, caused pretty much by the continued hiatus in demand in call routing from service providers. 
Turning to industrial and automotive. Net sales here declined 11% sequentially due to inventory, correction, in the supply chain during Q4 fiscal '12. On the other hand, we believe industrial demand has bottomed and demand continues to be, in fact, to be largely flat and lightly, gradually improving going forward. Looking at Q1, OEM demand for industrial fiber and LED products in particular has been picking up and continues to do so. We expect global resales in industrial to continue to be flat during this holiday season. However, we do expect to see contraction in distribution supply chain worldwide, therefore, driving industrial revenue to decline low to mid-single digits on a percentage basis compared to Q4. 
With this as background and in summary, I will just add, we grew to 2% sequentially in the fourth quarter driven primarily by strength in wireless. Q1, wireless demand remained steady, however, supply chain contraction in industrial and weak call routing spending will drive our overall revenue to decline between 5% to 9% as compared to Q4. 
With that, let me now turn the call over to Doug for a more detailed review of our fourth quarter financials.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext:
Okay, thanks, Hock. Good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for joining the call. Before reviewing the fourth quarter and fiscal 2012 financial results, I want to remind you that my comments today, as always, will focus primarily on our non-GAAP numbers. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release that we issued today and it's also available on our website at avagotech.com.
Revenue of $618 million in Q4 represents an increase of 2% from last quarter and a decrease of 1% versus the same quarter a year ago. The sequential increase was essentially in line with our guidance for the quarter. Revenue from our wireless target market came in at the upper end of our expectations. Revenue from our wired target market came in approximately as we expected, maybe a little bit better. And then finally, as Hock took you through, revenue from our industrial target market was a little weaker than what we thought a quarter ago, and that was driven by a contraction in our supply chain. 
For the last 2 quarters, we disclosed that Foxconn was a greater than 10% customer and when we file the K, you'll see that they continue to be one again this quarter. We saw the third consecutive quarter of growth in distribution resales in our 3 primary target markets. However, at the same time we saw resales improve, we also saw distribution inventory fall. This dynamic is the main reason we saw our industrial market revenues decline. 
Our Q4 gross margin was 51.1%, which was slightly below the midpoint of the guidance that we provided. This result was driven primarily by a stronger finish in our lower-margin wireless target margin, and a weaker finish in our higher-margin industrial market. 
Now let me turn to operating expenses. R&D in Q4 came in -- or I should say decreased by $8 million to $75 million, while SG&A increased by $1 million to $43 million, which drove operating expenses in total to $117 million, which was $7 million below last quarter's $124 million. 
OpEx also came in $7 million lower than our guidance and this was due primarily to lower variable compensation accruals as a result of lower attainment of our business and financial metrics. As a percentage of sales, R&D dropped to 12% and SG&A remained flat at 7% of net revenue. 
Given the swing in OpEx in Q4, I wanted to pause just for a minute and give you some color around how variable compensation at Avago works. The annual target for variable comp is in a range of $45 million to $50 million per year. This payout is based on attainment of overall corporate financial targets as well as organizational performance metrics, some of which are financial. It's typical that at the beginning of our fiscal year, we provide, on a pro rata basis, for 100% payout. We then true these estimates up each quarter. Some of the quarterly variation in spending is driven by our changing view of how attainment versus these goals will come out. We saw this specifically during Q4 when we took our accrual down. As you will see in a minute, the growth in spending for Q1 is based on our estimate of a 100% payout of variable compensation for fiscal 2013. Our philosophy here is simple. It is that when the company is doing well, our employee should get paid well and when we're missing our goals, we should all get paid less. It aligns incentives pretty well here. 
Now let me go back to Q4. Income from operations for the quarter increased by $13 million sequentially to $199 million and represented 32% in net revenue. Compared to the $191 million of Q4 in last year, income from operations increased by $8 million. We recorded a net gain of $1 million in interest and other. Taxes in Q4 came in at $6 million. Net income of $194 million increased 7% from the prior quarter and Q4 earnings per diluted share of $0.77 was $0.05 higher than Q3. Compared to Q4 of last year, net income was $8 million higher and for earnings per diluted share it was $0.04 higher. Earnings are higher versus the prior year primarily due to the lower spending that I described above. The lower increase in Q4 earnings -- or excuse me, the sequential increase in Q4 earnings was primarily attributed to higher revenue as well as the lower OpEx. 
I'd like to point out that both operating as well as net income in Q4 were record highs for Avago. Our share-based compensation in Q4 was $14 million, the breakdown of the expense for Q4 includes $2 million in cost of goods sold, $5 million in R&D and $7 million in SG&A. In Q1, I anticipate share-based comp will be approximately $17 million. And just to remind you, the company's definition of non-GAAP net income excludes share-based compensation. 
So I go to the balance sheet now. Our DSO came in at 51 days. This was up 1 day from the prior quarter. The increase was due to the linearity of revenue within the quarter, which was driven primarily by the timing of product ramps in our wireless target market. Our inventory ended at $194 million, which was a decrease of $22 million from last quarter. Days on hand came in at 58 days, which decreased 8 days from Q3. Q4 inventory declined from Q3 primarily because we accumulated inventory in Q3 in anticipation of the Q4 wireless revenue growth, and in Q4, we shipped that inventory. We ended the quarter with a cash balance of $1,084,000,000 and we generated $215 million in operational cash flow. 
And just to foreshadow Q1 a bit for you, Q1 is generally a little bit weaker quarter for cash generation due to the payment of our annual variable compensation relating to prior fiscal year. We spent $73 million on new CapEx, this was at the lower end of our guidance for the quarter, and it was mainly due to the timing of equipment delivery. 
In Q1, we expect CapEx to be in the range of $75 million to $85 million. The increase is primarily due to the ongoing build-out of incremental FBAR filter capacity to support growing customer demand. 
For fiscal 2013, I now expect CapEx will be roughly flat to maybe slightly up from fiscal year 2012. The continued investment will be primarily in FBAR as Hock described and a little bit in the wired infrastructure area. During the quarter, we repurchased approximately 294,000 shares, which consumes $10 million of cash. On October 1, we paid a quarterly cash dividend of $0.16 per ordinary share and that consumed $39 million of cash. This dividend was raised by $0.01 from the prior quarter. And I just point out, since the inception of our dividend program in Q1 of 2011, we have continued to increase our dividend each quarter. We also continue to evaluate potential strategic investments and acquisitions as another way of deploying cash to enhance shareholder returns. 
Let me now briefly recap our fiscal 2012 full year results. Revenue increased by 1% to approximately $2.4 billion driven by the strength in our wireless business. Gross margin declined by 70 basis points to 51%, also driven by the slight decline also due to the strength of our wireless business. Net income for 2012 increased to $700 million or $2.77 per diluted share, and that compares with $692 million or $2.70 per diluted share in fiscal 2011. 
Let me now turn to our non-GAAP guidance for the first quarter of fiscal 2013. I'll just let you know Q1 will be a 14-week long quarter, which happens every 5 or 6 years here for us. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions and we don't intend to update this guidance. As Hock told you, revenue is expected to be down in the range of 5% to 9% over Q4, caused by the weakness in call routing as well as the continued contraction in the industrial supply chain. I expect gross margin to be approximately 50.5%, plus or minus 1 percentage point. The slight sequential decline is primarily a result of the end market revenue mix. Operating expenses are estimated to be $130 million and, as I explained earlier, this was driven by an increase in our variable compensation accruals. Interest and other is projected to be a gain of approximately $1 million. Taxes are forecasted to be approximately $7 million. And finally, the diluted share count forecast is for 253 million shares. 
Let me just remind you, this quarter will be the last time that we report consumer and computing as a stand-alone target market. Starting with Q1 of next year, we'll group the remaining revenues from this business with industrial given the insignificant size of the remaining consumer revenue. And I just mentioned, revenue from consumer was down sharply in Q4 due to the last time buys in Q3, and we expect what remains as consumer revenue will be down again in Q1. We'll provide you with a recast of historical information in the earnings tables next quarter, so this change is clear. 
That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, please go ahead and open up the call for questions.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of Terence Whalen with Citi.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: I guess the first question would be on the comment that Hock made regarding quadrupling in FBAR capacity, that seems like it's an incremental update from what you had last shared with us. Specifically, what I wanted to understand is what the gross margin effect on wireless will be, if you can help us understand the magnitude of that.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Yes, Terence, I'm not going to quantify it for you, except I think you know that the margin on FBAR, when we sell FBAR, is better than some of the other products we sell in wireless. And so Hock's comment is telling you that we expect wireless gross margin, in and of itself, to get better as we ramp FBAR.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Okay, terrific. And then perhaps the follow-up question that I have is around the call routing. It's a little bit of a surprise to see the magnitude of weakness 2 quarters in a row when some of the other competitors and peers in that space have actually seen some improvement. Can you help us understand what's driving that for Avago specifically, and do you have line of sight into that business improving in April?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Yes. A very interesting question, Terence, is on call routing, the products we supply -- these are fiber products we're supplying, proprietary fiber products I should add -- we're supplying to call routing is fairly unique. It’s proprietary by intent/definition, in the sense that there are not too many OEMs who make those call routers. They’re needed for very high volume, high bandwidth flow of data and usually invested in the backhaul side of any infrastructure development as opposed to the front side, which is more the base station display [ph]. This is really more related to backhaul as it connects interface to transport and those investments do tend to be rather lumpy. We do have some line of sight, but it does get lumpy and it’s fairly substantial each time a program comes in. I guess what I should have added is sitting here, looking ahead, as I used the word 'hiatus’ -- and it's true, there a hiatus in investment in call routing at this point by some service providers, but eventually such investments need to be made in order to create a bandwidth needed as there are more and more smartphones and especially LTE running. We do see, line of sight, that while this coming quarter -- this quarter, Q1, might continue weakness in call routing investments and for, therefore, demand for proprietary fiber products. We do see coming fall fairly shortly, broke a large program in China and probably another one in China later part in the year. You see one being recently awarded in Japan though it takes a while for it to translate into demand for our products, not very long. And we definitely do see with expansion of LTE networks, LTE networks in North America, for investments by carriers in North America to be made in call routing for the rest of this year. So we are pretty positive. So we do -- we are kind of, as I say, in the midst of a hiatus right now.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Just a question on the guidance and the per segment comment, it seems like if wireless is flat that the math barely gets you to the low end of your guidance range, the down 5 versus the down 9 end. Is there something I'm missing in the guidance range that, Hock, you gave to explain how you would get to the mid or lower end of your guidance range?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: You should understand what is left of consumer, Ross, is going to decline also. So you've got about a $10 million drop off, if we were giving you that next quarter. That might be why your numbers aren't adding up.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Great. That's helpful to know. And then I guess as a more forward-looking question here, the extra week that you guys have in the January quarter, how should we think about that impacting both the revenue and OpEx side of the equation, not only in the January quarter but also in the April quarter?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: That's a simple thing. It's more likely to impact expenses than revenue. We'll have one more week of expenses, that's for sure. It’s been given by how it runs. But for that November to January quarter, when you pretty much have Christmas and New Year's break in between, I think from a revenue point of view, historically, we're not seeing much change in terms of how it runs compared to previous -- to other quarters in the fiscal year. But expenses, with 14 weeks will definitely add an extra week of spending.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: And Ross, our guidance comprehends the extra week in both items, revenue and expenses.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: So that 130 was not just a variable pop back to 100% payout but also the inclusion of the extra week?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: The biggest thing is the variable comp but there's other stuff in there as well. I don't always give you every single detail, but variable comp is the biggest, but certainly the extra week is part also.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis with Barclays.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Hock, I was wondering if you could talk about, you talk about sell-through industrial or sellout being flat by reducing inventory. Can you compare this to the levels you saw last January when the business did bottom out? And how close are we to those levels?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: We are pretty close to that level right now. We're in [indiscernible] and in first quarter fiscal '12 is when there was Thai floods, too -- those big floods in Thailand and that's when it's hitting our industrial business as plenty many others industrial and automotive business all over the world. And that tends to -- that drew down a lot in inventory at distributors worldwide. Because of that -- simply because they couldn't ship much into distributors and end customers were pulling it out, out of these 3 channels. We are -- by the time we end this quarter, Q1, we would be pretty close to that level.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: And then on the wireless, I guess flattish with the extra week is a little bit down. You talked about strength of your top 2, so does that just mean the non-top 2 are seeing weakness? And then can you talk about your outlook for the rest of the year and whether you see yourself as a share gainer as you go through the year?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: For -- well, I guess trying to look ahead on wireless -- by the way, I have to qualify that to say, we seem to be in a room here, in wireless, where things change all the time. Year-on-year, to tell you experiencing one year doesn't mean it's the same the next year. And frankly, what we've -- I mean, as I've indicated to you guys I think a few months ago, we expected this quarter, Q1, wireless to be relatively flat from the preceding quarter, which is typically our strongest quarter in any 12-month period and its -- as we see it here now, we have Q1 running at the same rate as Q4. And -- but we do see -- it depends on how fast the product transitions occur at those 2 major OEMs. I think that's what, more than anything else, drives -- the characteristic that drives what one would call the ups and downs of the wireless business for us. And in other words, if the launch of new ramps on those -- one of those 2 OEMs, or both those 2 OEMs occur earlier, and as you saw in this year '12, it launched around September, October time frame, kind of later. But if that thing were to be pulled forward then probably product transition quarter would occur probably earlier than this year. This year it occurred in our fiscal Q3. If these things will pull forward, which it possibly could, though we don't know. It's too early to know. Then it could move forward one quarter, or it could push back one quarter, and could still be remaining -- remain at Q3 as we did in calendar '12. So given the information I have right now, I would probably say, most likely, we'll have the same situation as we had this year. Product transition in wireless, which means the lowest quarter of the year, would occur in our fiscal Q3. But I could be wrong by one quarter.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Romit Shah with Nomura.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Hock, I was somewhat encouraged just by your comments on industrial, even though it’s down in January, you mentioned that industrial demand or resales is flat to improving. Is that a trend that you guys have observed more recently?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: No, we have seen that now for 3 quarters in a row. Okay? Resale has been -- which, and as you know, most of our industrial business goes through distributors, not all, but I would say 85%, 90% of it goes through distributors. And based on resale, our industrial business has, in fact, been flat, virtually flat, the last 3 quarters. And so I would say we are definitely in the trough and we probably looking at it, probably slowly, gradually creeping up from the trough, especially when it comes to China.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Then, my follow-up would be, how do we think about the normalized -- what normalized revenues are for this segment. Because on your January guidance, it looks like industrial will be around 130 million to 135 million, that's up from where it was a year ago, but it's still well below the 180-plus you guys were doing in the back half of 2011.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Right. Well, as I said, because it goes through distribution and we recognize revenue and you've correctly pointed out on shipped into our channels, you will see in periods of volatility -- on periods of uncertainty, I should say, this sort of thing happening. And part of it relates to the fact that tracing back to the beginning of this fiscal '12, another way of putting it, beginning of calendar '12, when we were just -- when we were experiencing, like many other industrial component manufacturers, the Thai flood at that time. We obviously, had to draw down substantially, our end customers have drawn down substantially on channel inventory to meet their needs and we weren't able to replenish those channel inventory in, obviously, a timely manner and that was the beginning of '12. And we obviously started to replenish it in our fiscal Q2 and fiscal Q3. And since then, we've been drawing back down -- the distribution channels had been bringing down the inventory levels quite significantly. And that's pretty much what we're seeing over the course of fiscal '12 and that's why -- and to answer -- an answer to an earlier question from the audience was that by the end of this fiscal quarter, our inventory level in the channel would be as low as it was in January calendar '12 when we had the Thai floods and when inventory has really been drawn down. But through all this, my point is, as it gyrates our revenue, shipping that is, resale has been pretty flat.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Hock, first one on wireless, I'm curious how your visibility is and your design wins in the flagship smartphone products for 2013. Do you think you'll be able to maintain your content in terms of absolute dollars for phone, because as you also acknowledged your top customers have a habit of changing suppliers with every generation of phone?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: You said it exactly. These guys have a habit for going for the things they need, be it the best performance or the best price. And it depends on the program they are engaged in and it depends on the OEMs themselves, and usually we have visibility out 6 months, good visibility out about 6 months. So it’s limited but out 6 months, and sometimes 9 months. And that's the extent of it.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: But Vivek, we wouldn't be investing CapEx if weren't feeling pretty good about the broad market need for FBAR. So we're talking to people, we don't know the exact design wins but we kind of know what they're going to need, and we kind of know where they're going to need to come to get the performance that FBAR provides.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: The trend is very clear, especially when you went from CDMA to 3G, and now from particularly from 3G to 4G or LTE, and the proliferation of smartphones that are LTE enabled, which doesn't mean they're just LTE, as I said before, they go backward compatible to 3G and 2G and CDMA, which basically puts a lot of bands and requirements on any particular piece of a device, which basically creates a lot of, what we have said before, coexistence problems. And all that rolls into a situation where, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, a situation where, when 5 years ago maybe 1 or 2 bands in the spectrum uses FBAR. Today, we have 15, 1-5, bands that uses FBAR. Of course, the number of bands have proliferated since then. I mean 5, 6 years ago maybe there were less than 10 bands. Today, there are 40 bands. But having said that, out of 40 bands, 15 uses FBAR. So those kind of trends and demand and the proliferation of smartphones and content in basically those smartphones is what's driving the need for us to expand occupancy in a fairly, fairly radical manner.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: And then follow-up, Hock, if you look at your top customer, they have already made the move to LTE and the last time they made the move to 3G, the next generation of phones, RF content probably came down because they were able to integrate different components. So now that they have already made the move to 4G/LTE, do you think it's possible that their next 1 or 2 products RF content perhaps on a like-to-like basis comes down because they're able to take advantage of integration and just a competition in the RF front end market?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: It is possible, though, I mean, we are talking a bit conceptual here. So please bear in mind in the audience when I say it. It's possible because you're right, they'll try to integrate. I mean the number of bands hasn't changed. In fact, the number of bands will increase as we go into more and more LTE in various parts of the world, offsetting that number of bands with more content in theory, linearly but in practice your point is taken. The integration, also, that's right, the consolidation of RF components will reduce the content the other direction. Having said that, I do want to remind you from our very self-interest biased point of view, you tend to see that -- you can see that in power amplifiers, you don't see that in filters or duplexers. You cannot integrate duplexers or filters. Every band needs a separate filter. You don't integrate them together. But power amplifiers have been, as we have seen in our recent 8960 Qualcomm chipset have -- it supports power amplifiers 2G and some of the 3G bands integrated as 1 single chip solution in power amplifiers. But for duplexes and filters, which is the main thrust of interest for this company, it never gets integrated.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Chin with UBS.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: I'd like to ask a couple more follow-up questions on industrial, just to better calibrate my understanding there. But in the past I know that emerging markets, such as China was a big part of the growth in your industrial story, is that still the case now or is North America and Europe a big component of what's driving the trends there? And then secondly, from -- in terms of product areas, are alternative energy power electronics that's still something that is maybe on the rise or playing some factor and add variability in your industrial demand?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: I apologize, I didn't quite catch the first question you asked. I know the second was about alternative energy.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: I think, Stephen, you were asking if China still drives our industrial business as much as it used to, right?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Okay, good question. And it's a question I don't really know 100%. It's not as obvious it is driving, and so the best answer is not as much as it used to in the heydays of 2010 and definitely part of 2011, much less now. But it still does have an impact and quite a big impact because the multinational, industrial multinationals, we sell into Central Europe and into Japan, and a good part on North America, export a fair amount of their products into China -- for China programs. So it does have that, it still drives part of it but much less than it used to. If you ask me to quantify how much, I'm not sure. I couldn't quantify that. But it drives -- it has a much less impact, and which is probably the reason why we're seeing industrial resale among Tier 2, Tier 3, which tends to go through distribution a lot, to be very flat in countries like North America, and in countries like -- and more than flat, declining, in countries like Europe and Japan, offset by gradual increase in industrial resale in places like China and in emerging countries. So it -- and it balances out globally industrial resale, what we have seen over the last 9 months has been virtually flat. On the second question on renewable energy, there are 2 parts to it, but the major part you're talking about is demand into solar, wind, those kind of renewable energy things. Yes, there was strength a few years ago in the period of 2009, 2010. It's pretty strong. From 2011 onwards, things have come down quite dramatically and is now, I think, strong to a relatively small percentage of our total industrial business, probably maybe down to about 5%, 10%.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Lipacis with Jefferies.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Two easy questions. First on FBAR, what's your market share now, what do you think it will do over the next year or 2? And second, on the FBAR business, can you help us understand to what extent you get attached or you sell the FBAR part, which you guys have a great position in and you get attach rates of other silicon in the handset?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: To answer the first part of your question, what's the -- and I'll rephrase your question, it's kind of -- and I apologize for doing it but I'll rephrase your question to answer, it's not really our share in FBAR as much as the filter business, what penetration is FBAR? And I say, as I mentioned before, in simple terms, the 40 bands right now roughly operating in the world, 40 cellular bands, and 15 of that do use FBAR. It doesn't mean every one of them use it. So if I were to guess at market penetration by handsets, I would probably say 20% only, if at all. 15%, 20% is FBAR, may be even less, which is an interesting turn. It gives us a lot of room to grow. But only 15%, 20% uses FBAR at this point and that includes all the LTE bands. And the way FBAR pulls other components, that's very interesting, a good question and I'd like to highlight that and it refers back to an earlier question about, if FBAR is sold discreetly, that means as a standalone duplex or filter, FBAR creates a lot of gross margin, generates a very high gross margin for us. But they do not sell on its own most of the time. You pay an FBAR or you bet -- it pulls with it power amplifiers usually. Among other, small other components, largely power amplifiers. And so that's kind of dilute or makes [indiscernible] necessary thing that it gives us content and a lot of times those 2 pull together is packaged in a front end module, as we call it, or as some people call it FEM [ph] or front end modules. And which basically gives a higher price, higher dollar content but relatively lower margin. But as more of this front end modules requires FBAR, obviously, it’s also good for us in improving not only our dollars but our margin, but it typically -- not typically, but I would say 75% at least of our volume of FBAR are sole FEM [ph] with power amplifiers.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of JoAnne Feeney with Longbow Research.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Question on the FBAR capacity expansion. So in the past, you talked about doubling capacity by the middle of 2013. Today you said quadruple, I'm wondering if that's just a change in your starting point of comparison or if you've actually doubled your intentions. And, if so, can you tie that to CapEx for the year? And then I have a follow-on.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Yes, we've doubled our intention JoAnne, and it's because we're going a little further out in time. And so that's why I told you next year CapEx will be at least as high as it was in 2012 and maybe slightly higher. And Hock mentioned the fact that, cumulatively, between what we've already invested and what we will invest in 2013, it will be $300 million on FBAR alone.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: And I would add a little bit more. It's not that we change our intent, improve or increase our intention. We’ll still pull forward a part of that. So from 2011 to today, to early next year, we would have doubled the capacity and by in about another year's time, we will double it again.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then could you give us a sense of how that might affect gross margin. What I'm wondering, in particular, is the timing of when this new capacity comes online and how that matches up to the programs you see demanding your FBAR products.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: JoAnne, it kind of comes in -- the way we do this as it comes in tool by tool and we try to do it such that we'd bring the constraint tools in and it gradually increases capacity. And if we're good at doing this, we'll match it with demand. You don't always get that exactly right.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: We expected to trend gross margin up, but it's a trend not a spike. And it's hard to predict it accurately at this point, other than to be able to tell you, it will continue to trend out this capacity. headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: And your next question comes from Ian Ing with Lazard Capital Markets.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: So given the fall off in call routing, what's the mix between proprietary and standard optics, is it still 50-50? And for standard optics, what's the pricing environment right now given the current demand?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: So it's a little bit more standard than it used to be given the fall off in parallel, Ian. I don't know, Hock, you want to take the pricing question?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: The pricing question, optics always has this price -- a downward price trend line in semiconductor products which is considered as, though I don't think is really a semiconductor product. It's a normal pricing environment we see today and we -- which is roughly, frankly, depending on which particular generation of product it is, somewhere in the range of anywhere from 5% to 10% annually is what we tend to see in our mix of fiber optic products. Obviously the newer products tends to ramp down faster and stabilizes. The older products pretty much stays firm. The other products being the 1G tends to be more firm, 10, 100, if you imagine that still exists, still it's more firm. And the newer 8 gigabit per second storage product or 10 gigabit per second would tend to start off at a higher price and move down much faster. So the mix of that, I would say, on a steady-state basis will range from 5% to 10% a year, sometimes into the low double digits.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Aalok Shah with D.A. Davidson.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Just a real quick clarification, can you go over that consumer business again. So does that business go down about another $10 million going into the January quarter and then you're going to include it in the industrial business?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: You have it exactly right, Aalok.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Okay. And then if we look at kind of how you're thinking about the FBAR business, it does sound like that the seasonality is changing again next year, how do you guys view -- I mean, I know you don't you want to give me full guidance, but are you guys seeing a change in how handsets are being delivered or designed for next year?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: No, I think it's the same way. It's just that the dynamic, it is still very much there for most parts. I guess you do -- you probably see 2 big guys and a host of other significant OEM guys out there. And you still have the -- there's still seasonality for the most part which comes at this time of the year and everybody tries to get their products launched before or towards the seasonality. But the difference also is there are 1 or 2 of those big OEMs who go through more than one significant product launches a year, and the other big one do it once a year. And so you still see that, but it tweaks, one, as a component supplier to everyone, we see each year somewhat. In the old days when the OEM makers we're all not that far back in size, so for more or less about the same size, we do see the seasonality of year end, Christmas, year-end becomes very pronounced. Today, the seasonality is pronounced for the significant OEM but because of also the way size [ph] is shifted, that seasonality gets to a large extent muted by the size of the 2 big guys continuing their strong ramps.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Walkley with Cannacord Genuity.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: This is Matt Ramsay on for Mike. The first question, Hock, it’s fairly well understood which 2 of the unnamed dominant smartphone OEMs are driving your wireless business. A quick question there, were each of those 2 both 10% customers in the quarter or only your leading one?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Matt, we don't disclose unless it's a 10% customer and my scripted remarks purposely gave you Foxconn as a 10% customer, and that's all I have to tell you.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Fair enough. And as a follow-up, now that your leading customer has included LTE and all their global SKUs, we've seen in our checks other high Tier OEMs, maybe forced to follow suit and Qualcomm's LTE baseband solutions are definitely well positioned in that market. Hock, maybe you could talk a little bit about your FBAR alignment with Qualcomm's LTE road map and reference designs relative to your competitors and maybe your attach rate with Qualcomm's LTE wins to this point?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Well, I mean, the best way for me to describe is we're obviously very, very closely engaged in enabling Qualcomm on our [indiscernible] with both our FBAR duplexers as well as our PA designs as well as front end designs and a combination of anything else in RF they need. And we're obviously very, very well engaged with them on that, and it definitely benefits us a lot to do that and we continue to do that. But in terms of specifics, pretty hard, that's a lot of designs. There are many, many designs that keep pouring out, and I can't even begin to tell you how many we have engaged in versus how many that are out there. Just sufficient that we do have, we have very close engagement. Not only just with Qualcomm but at -- to the OEMs who takes those reference design and do not necessarily follow those reference designs either.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Danely with JPMorgan.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: This is Sameer Kalucha calling in for Chris Danely. The question I have is around taxes. The taxes have been in the $15 million, $20 million range as you pointed out during the IPO. But at that time you also said you had visibility into the next 3, 4 years going forward. I wonder how the visibility in tax holidays is at this point? Do you expect it to continue for another, I would say, 2, 3, 4, 5 years or is it subject to change?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: The visibility is much longer than that. For the indefinite future, our effective tax rate will be 4% to 5%, it's not going away. Our tax holidays are double-digit number of years, and we work to extend them all the time.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: And then a lot of people and some of your peers have also expressed some possibility of a snapback in macro demand going past once the uncertainties on fiscal cliffs and those sorts have cleared. I wonder does that change year outlook in, say, April time frame if that uncertainty is clear from the flattish resales you're seeing right now?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: It's hard for us to -- sitting here right now to know for sure with any of degree of certainty that, that would happen and as I said, we only focus all the way out with any degree of guidance level that we have here to the end of this quarter, beyond that, who knows? I'll be honest, we have no clue.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brendan Furlong with Miller Tabak.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: Two quick questions, both on gross margins. I don't know if my first question has been addressed, but how much of the downtick in gross margin in fiscal Q1 is mix related versus utilization be it back end, front end and what the implication of that would be in the April quarter?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: It's primarily mix, Brendan.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: And then the second question I have, following off from JoAnne's question, you were expecting to double your capacity in the middle of next year and then your comment on gross margins for FBAR after that. So should we assume that the feed through on the gross margin side happens in the second half of your fiscal year? We don't see it for the first half in other words?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 29, 2012
componenttext: It should in the second half and as FBAR gets to be a bigger and bigger percentage of the mix, which we see that happening as we go through the back part of 2013, you should begin to see it trickle its way through.
